awd_titl_txt: Entrainment, Decoupling, and Vertical Transport in the Marine Stratocumulus Cloud Deck
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine stratocumulus clouds cover significant areas of the ocean and act to cool the planet by reflecting incoming sunlight.  The processes behind these low clouds are not well simulated by weather or climate models.  This award will allow researchers to analyze data that was collected in a prior field campaign so that they can study the movement of air and moisture within marine stratocumulus clouds.  The result will be a better understanding of the clouds and an improved ability to model their formation, dissipation, and impacts.  One main impact of the research will be on weather forecasting with a focus on low clouds and fog, which are hazards for the aviation industry.  The work will also help to improve climate models.  Training and diversity impacts will be provided through the incorporation of students into the research plan.

The research team will conduct an analysis of lidar, radar and sounding data from the 2008 VAMOS Ocean Cloud Atmosphere Land Study (VOCALS) to better understand the processes that control the structure, transitions, and radiative properties of stratocumulus clouds.  The researchers note that vertical mixing is poorly observed in stratocumulus cloud top entrainment, in cumulus updrafts rising into stratocumulus, and in evaporative downdrafts.  Conceptual and numerical models of these phenomena have only been evaluated by their effects on external phenomena, rather than how well the models represent the actual internal processes themselves.  Three scientific objectives are identified that will lead to a better description and understanding of entrainment, decoupling, and coherent updraft and downdraft fluxes:  1) Relating entrainment to the strength of turbulence in the stratocumulus cloud and documenting diurnal variations of turbulence and its transport due to variation of buoyancy flux at cloud top, 2) Documenting the structure and evolution of turbulence leading to decoupling between the stratocumulus cloud and surface mixed layer, and analyzing both diurnal decoupling driven by the cycle of solar radiation, and decoupling associated with large-scale cold advection over warm SST, and 3) quantifying mass transports due to cumulus updrafts and downdrafts generated by negative buoyancy from cloud and drizzle evaporation, and attributing the observed distributions of vertical velocity to turbulence strength, decoupling, cumulus clouds, and drizzle.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Earth’s radiative balance the depends on stratocumulus clouds. Reflecting sunlight, marine stratocumulus clouds have a cooling effect on Earth’s climate. The quality of climate model projections of the future climate depends on the models’ representation of how stratocumulus clouds respond to the warming of the surface temperature and the atmosphere’s response to CO2 and greenhouse gases. Yet climate and weather models do not represent large tropical and subtropical stratocumulus cloud decks well in the present climate, affecting the radiative heat balance of the atmosphere and upper ocean, and affecting large-scale atmosphere circulations.

This project analyzed turbulence in the marine atmospheric boundary layer (MABL) from ship-based remotely sensed Doppler cloud radar and lidar observations. When combined with complementary ship observations, these analyses add to our understanding of the processes that control the structure, transitions, and radiative properties of the stratocumulus clouds. This understanding is needed to improve the cloud and turbulence parameterizations on which climate models depend. High-resolution observations of southeastern tropical Pacific stratocumulus clouds were made from aircraft and ships during the Variability of the American Monsoon Systems Ocean-Cloud-Atmosphere-Land Study Region Experiment (VOCALS-REx).

This project observationally estimated the contributions heat, moisture, and turbulent kinetic energy (TKE) budgets of the marine atmospheric boundary layer, specifically their daily cycles, which varied according to the rising and setting of the sun. First, the project modeled the vertical transfer of solar and thermal infrared radiation in the cloudy boundary layer. Second, these radiative fluxes were used with other observations to construct the heat and water budget. The heat and water budget are linked through condensation warming and evaporative cooling. Another key link between the heat and water budgets that affects the clouds, is the entrainment of air, heat, and water into the boundary layer from above. Third, the project combined the heat and water budgets into the buoyancy flux, which is the main term in the TKE budget. Fourth the TKE budget was estimated using the buoyancy flux and remotely sensing estimates of other terms in the TKE budget.

Key outcomes of this work are that it (1) characterizes the daily cycle of turbulence throughout the depth of the atmospheric boundary layer, (2) identifies the vertical structure of turbulence and buoyancy flux in coupled and decoupled boundary layers, and (3) estimate cloud-top entrainment rates. The budgets of heat, moisture, and TKE are needed to test parameterization of turbulent mixing processes in stratocumulus-topped marine boundary layer in weather and climate models.

Broader Impacts: Understanding stratification, entrainment, and decoupling of marine clouds informs the representation of clouds and their important radiative effects in climate models. The methods developed in this project are used for forecasting marine visibility, affecting safety and cost for operation and transportation at sea. The project trained a PhD graduate, who continues to work on important aspects of stratocumulus clouds and marine visibility. The PhD graduate is a consultant. Among other projects, she develops forecast systems for marine visibility for government and industry.
